text: security guard whilst operating security barrier trapped their finger and sustained small cut & bruising to finger. at approximately 12.30 on thursday 23rd june 2016 security guard employed by amec foster wheeler security contractor top class security went to open the security gate/bar at moray yard compound to allow vehicle to enter.when the guard pushed down on the counterweight they for some unknown reason put their finger in the hole where the bolts goes in once the gate/ bar is upright.as the counterweight came downwards the guards finger became trapped between the counterweight and the main body of the pillar. the guard managed to remove finger before it became fully trapped.the left index finger sustained two small cuts to finger. guard cleaned finger and apply elastoplast dressings to the 2 small cuts, next day there was minor bruising the finger and the guard reported the incident to dominic canning (afw construction manager).in turn reported to micky arkley (afw hsse advisor), guard was spoken to and micky arkley visually checked the finger, small bruising and cuts were clean. guard informed to change elastoplast's and keep clean.all guards have been informed not to put fingers near the bolt hole and warning sign erected.

ip received a small abrasion to his lower back as he stood up within a scaffold. ip was performing concrete patching work from a scaffold. as ip stood-up from a kneeling position, his lower back came into contact with a nearby scaffold rosette resulting in a minor abrasion. ip stopped work and reported the event to supervisor and hse team.employee was escorted to the site paramedic for assessment. the area was cleaned and bandage applied.client notified of the event.

subcontract employee tested positive for covid-19. zadok (tier 2 subcontractor) employee tested positive for covid19 on saturday 7/26/2020.  nine co-workers have been quarantined for close contact. employee and all close contacts triaged by occucare clinic and quarantined away from project per project protocol.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: ee backed into parked vehicle while driving rental car ee was backing out of parking space and did not see vehicle parked behind.  ee backed into parked vehicle, causing minor damage to front grille/bumper of parked vehicle verified no injuries and took pictures/exchanged information

wire wheel abrasion on arm employee was using a wire wheel on a 4 inch grinder to clean up an area for a future weld. the grinder kicked back and grazed the employee’s right bicep. the employee was wearing the proper ppe and the grinder did have the proper guard and handle attached.  employee was brought to wood safety where permission was given for the employee to evaluated and basic first aid given. the employee admitted to not being in the best body position and it was reiterated how important proper body position is. the employee will be checked in on again at the end of the day to make sure the abrasion has not gotten any worse.

unmarked line discovery.  no injuries or equipment damage of any kind were incurred. migrated from legacy cairs incident #36528on 02/27/18 we were notified by project supervisor, that equipment operator (eo) and swamper discovered a private farmer’s unmarked underground conduit connecting to a land owner’s irrigation “center pivot” sprinkler. eo and swamper were tasked to excavate a bellhole and expose a 20” gas line and 8” oil line for hot tapping; both lines were parallel to each other in an east/west direction. eo completed exposing both lines, digging a walk-out ramp on the west side of the bellhole, then proceeded to dig the walk-out on the east side of the bellhole. as he was completing the ramp on the east side he discovered the un-marked, privately owned conduit heading north to south at approximately 6-8” in depth. operations were shutdown immediately and the crew made the proper notifications. no injuries or equipment damage of any kind were incurred.one-calls are up-to-date (a804501234) and the row was pre-swept by our line locator on 02/07/18. it is important to note here that the state run 811 one-call program only locates utilities that are state owned or owned by a corporation; 811 will not locate privately owned lines, such is the case here. the only way to locate privately owned lines is to pre-sweep the area with your own locator, such as we did here. after having conversations with our locator, regarding the pre-sweep, he stated that the power lines were likely not picked up due the fact that there was interference from the 20” poly water line, 20” gas, and an 8” oil line all within a 15’ area of our dig site. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: alcohol or drugs, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: latent report suggesting ip jumped from a pe coil trailer causing light bruising to ankle  team member had stated that he was attempting to free a 180mm cap that had become lodged against the rear gate of a coil trailer with a shovel. as the cap end became free, the ip jumped backwards and landed upright on both feet and struck the back of his right hand against the trailer cross bar. the ip sustained minor bruising to both ankles and right hand. the ip failed to report the incident but had only came to light when he bumped into his operations controller whilst out within the town area 4 days after the event. no immediate action was taken. ip in work the following day (friday) but had only mentioned it to the operations controller whilst under the influence of alcohol on the sunday whilst out and about in local town. ip decided to go to a&e the following monday (29th) to assess his ankle swelling where he was diagnosed as having soft tissue damage to is right ankle (no treatment was provided at a&e). note: this was not reported immediately hence delay in uploading information to oneaim.

2 amsc employees tested positive for covid19.  2 amsc employees tested positive for covid19. they are both asymptomatic and is now being monitored by our company oh team. the case was referred to the local government health team for coordination, recording. the ips was sent home for isolation is now monitored by wood oh team.

ee felt pain in the palm of right hand while using a 3 pound mallet employee was placing post caps on posts. this requires the use of a 3 pound mallet to tap the cap on, over the top of the post. the employee experienced pain in the palm of the right hand, just under the thumb  cold therapy and anti-inflammatory.
ip tested +ve for covid ip tested +ve for covid ip isolated. no ccs

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: slowering scaffold tray, bumped hand rail. hand rail came loose operator was lowering a tray of scaffold parts from the second level of the turbine building. the tray struck the hand rail. when the hand rail was struck, it became dislodged because the welds to the posts holding the removable hand rail broke. the investigation shows the welds have been broken for a while due to the rust. only a little of the weld was holding the hand rail posts in place. scaffold employees secured the hand rail in place using scaffolding as outriggers. called amecfw and had the posts properly welding in place

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19  a wood employee was reported to wood supervision that they began to experience cov19 s/s on 1/7/2022.  the wood employee scheduled a covid 19 test on 1/9/2022, and was informed on 1/10/2022 the employee is positive for cov19. the employee was last on site on 1/6/2022. contact tracing has been completed, no direct contacts identified.  employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

category: site compliance or practice issue, general injury, back injury
text: (bcll) - ratchet strap that was supporting jb box fell from crane boom hitting individual on the shoulder area (the ip was not working under a suspended load). migrated from legacy cairs incident #31329on the 11th september 2016 at approximately 13:45 on brent charlie, a small ratchet strap that was temporarily providing additional support to a junction box on the east crane boom, wore free and fell hitting individual on the back/shoulder as he was carrying out his work on the power generation scope within the pipe deck.job was stopped, crane boom placed in rest position and individual attended medic for treatment to injury.ice pack and pain killers were given and individual returned to normal working duties.investigation on going within the platform. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

qc inspector not 100% tie on a yellow tag scaffold at the 1st level scaffold.  a pec qc inspector was scheduled to carry out checks and was observed not 100% tie on a yellow tag scaffold at t21407 at 270 deg at the 1st level scaffold. he was observed to have walked 2m with his snap hook on his hand before hooking on the handrail as the handrail was covered with fire blankets. stopped work

wood/psns employee tested positive for covid-19. as part of destination country medical requirements of the destination country wood employee visited the contracted medical center for a pcr test before commencing his scheduled rotation leave travel, he was feeling well. test showed positive result for covid-19. ip was last in the office in a week before the incident happened on remote work and has no contacts with other employee. employee is in home quarantine at present, as mandated by russian requirements.  ip is in quarantine at home.

category: dropped object or material, line of fire
text: roof panel section tipped from vertical position during a rigging operation and struck employee. a roof panel section of waste heat duct for an auxiliary boiler, lying flat, was being rolled due to being upside down. using a 2-point pick, the panel was raised to the vertical position and approximately 6” off the ground. as the piece was being set back down, the rigging application (shake-out hooks) separated from the load and the panel fell over to the ground. according to witness statements, the assigned rigger moved toward the load, placing himself in the line of fire, when the panel fell thus pinning him from the waist down. the duct panel is 27.5’ x 6.5’ and approximately 2,000lbs.  all work stopped, site pa and rescue team responded.  local medical services contacted and injured employee was take to medical facility for evaluation.

a wood employee was embarked  on whpa. the ip performed the covid-19 test on february 7th with a positive result.  a wood employee was embarked  on whpa. the ip performed the covid-19 test on february 7th with a positive result. the ip is symptomatic the ip is symptomatic with sore throats. he received guidance from the nursing technician regarding the necessary care and will be sent home for quarantine period.
kaefer employees tested positive for covid at tac healthcare. kaefer employee tested positive for covid19 at his pre-mobilisation testing.  individual returned home and commenced isolation.

a worker hit his left thumb with a screwdriver, resulting in a small cut. an engeser's worker was installing a collar with screw, using a battery screwdriver. he lost the control of the tool, hitting his left thumb, with the result of a small cut. afw hse manager together with the operative first aider of bipso brought the worker to be check.

live instrument cable cut fd fan actuator whilst removing redundant instrument cables for 3f2a convertor, an adjacent cable in the same cable ladder which was live was cut by mistake.  instrument cable was signal cable to 3f2c fd fan guide van actuator.  outcome of cut cable was loss of signal to positioner which in turn made the actuator fail open. actuator went from 46% open to 100% open which made air flow go from 636tpd to 660tpd.  an alarm went off in the control room due to the lost signal. converter c continued to operate as normal with the increased air flow.  cable was repaired and actuator returned to service without loss of production.

subcontractor communicated a late positive confirmation for covid-19 to site management. subcontractor reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19. the subcontractor employee was placed in isolation.  subcontractor/wood identified those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed. there were total of 17 cases reported by this contractor.

while getting up from the rolling chair, the chair rolled back, and soft landing to grade. while getting up from the rolling chair (with 5 wheels) by supporting hands on the armrest, the chair rolled back, and he lost balance. consequently squat and soft-landed on his back on the ground.he was taken to the project medical facility as a precaution, no injury was reported or found, and the man was discharged fit to resume work.  replaced the chair with one having a bigger wheel base

due to leakage a welder was hit by the water from a live pipe a small leakage was started in the morning and was reported by irem and afw to em process (console). em took action to close the leakage, but unfortunately in the afternoon while the welder was welding in this area suddenly a lot of water came out. the afw supervisor noticed the welder was hit by the water. the water is approx. 60 degrees (cooling water). the leakage is caused by corrosion (maintenance).  em process is informed, em anwerup hse is informed, activities are suspended till further notification.

a truck of fagioli guided by spotters (3) came in contact with an existing fire hydrant. a truck of fagioli guided by spotters (3) came in contact with an existing fire hydrant. the fire hydrant suffered a minor damage. exxon mobil operation is informed and  inspected the involved fire hydrant.  investigation is already started with collection of pictures and will be continued on monday morning with the involvement of all personnel.

a wood employee tested positive for covid-19  a wood employee received a positive covid-19 test result on 1/15/2021.  the wood employee was experiencing symptoms and scheduled a covid 19 test which was a positive result.  contact tracing has been completed. employee has self quarantined and has notified management.  wood on site management has conducted contact tracing and notification to client.

preventable, company, minor damage, no iinjury. when leaving site, employee was parked in narrown trail through a treed area leading to worksite. when backing out of parked location, vehicle clipped a nearby small tree. upon impact with the tree, the plastic cover over the right taillight broke in pieces and a small dent in the truck body near taillight occured.  reported to supervisor, initated internal reporting procedures.

subcontractor bulldozer was pushing over a tree on a gravel covered slope and slowly rotated to its side. subcontractor was working at the bottom of a slope gravel covered slope.  bulldozer was trying to push a tree over and slowly rotated to its side.  no spills or injury, little or no damage to the equipment. notified wood of incident, reporting initiated.

inhalation of harmful substance-single episode frac technicians conducting monitoring operations on water levels of gauging tanks during oil and gas drilling operations are potentially overexposed to air contaminants and respiratory irritants such as chlorine, hydrogen sulfide, and benzene.  recently, an employee was admitted to the hospital for observation and treatment after suffering from an extreme coughing episode after working a monitoring shift at the worksite.  a second employee was treated and released.

text: vehicle or machinery fire on 4/26/16, at approximately 5:15 am, an employee was using a pneumatic chipping gun to break up hardened mortar inside the mortar mixer. when he connected his chipping gun's quick-connect hose to the airline, he accidentally hooked it to an oxygen line, which was not properly labeled.  while he was operating the chipping gun with oxygen instead of compressed air, a fire broke out inside the tool and enveloped his right arm, face, and neck. he suffered second and third degree burns to his arm, and first and second degree burns to his face and neck, requiring hospitalization.
